Definition: The input contains an argument and a keypoint on the topic "We should fight for the abolition of nuclear weapons", separated by "<sep>".Your task is to answer if the keypoint matches the argument and summarizes exactly what the argument means, in the context of this topic.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Having nuclear weapons actually stops nations from going to war because of the fear of how it might escalate<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons is essential for protection and deterrence
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that having nuclear weapons actually stops nations from going to war because of the fear of how it might escalate

Positive Examples.input: Argument: The use of nuclear weapons is a good tool to guard against mutual destruction.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons is essential for protection and deterrence
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that the use of nuclear weapons is a good tool to guard against mutual destruction.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Nuclear weapons have a capacity to wipe out an entire nation<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons can fall into the wrong hands
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that nuclear weapons have a capacity to wipe out an entire nation

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Nuclear weapons stop countries from attacking those that hold them and therefore protect those countries.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons is essential for protection and deterrence
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that nuclear weapons stop countries from attacking those that hold them and therefore protect those countries.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Nuclear weapons aid in deterring other countries from attacks and also symbolizes a countries world power.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons is essential for protection and deterrence
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that nuclear weapons aid in deterring other countries from attacks and also symbolizes a countries world power.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Nothing good comes from nuclear weapons. humans need to get along and work together for a better world instead of finding new ways to destroy the enemy.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons can fall into the wrong hands
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that nothing good comes from nuclear weapons. humans need to get along and work together for a better world instead of finding new ways to destroy the enemy.
